keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines on behalf of Emirates skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport during landing.
The aircraft struck a patrol car, which was on the other side of a fence, and both vehicles ended up in the sea water.
Two people were killed: a 30-year-old man confirmed dead at the scene and a 41-year-old man who died after being hospitalized.
The plane was a Boeing 747 leased from and operated by Turkish freight carrier ACT Airlines, representing a major cargo airline involved in the incident.
All four crew members on board were unharmed and received medical treatment at local hospitals.
The airport authority, led by Steven Yiu, confirmed the investigation into what caused the plane to leave the runway.
No emergency signal was sent by the aircraft, and weather and runway conditions were deemed safe.
Hong Kong police have not ruled out launching a criminal investigation, indicating potential legal or safety oversight concerns.
This was one of the most serious safety incidents at Hong Kong International Airport since its opening in 1998.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Boeing 747 cargo plane operated by Turkish freight carrier ACT Airlines on behalf of Emirates skidded off the north runway at Hong Kong International Airport during landing shortly before 4:00am on Monday, striking a security patrol car and causing both vehicles to sink into the sea. Two people were killed: a 30-year-old man at the scene and a 41-year-old man who died after being rushed to hospital. The aircraft did not send an emergency signal, and officials confirm that weather and runway conditions were safe. The Airport Authority, led by Steven Yiu, is investigating the cause of the skid, and Hong Kong police have not ruled out a criminal investigation. This marks one of the most serious safety incidents at Hong Kong’s busiest cargo airport since its opening in 1998.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off Hong Kong runway
